title: Who Uses Web Search for What? And How?

author: Ingmar Weber, Qatar Computing Research Institute

segmentation: OK, so welcome everybody.
So in this work that I will be presenting now, we sort of try to give a high level overview of who uses web search for what and how sort of how is web search used today.
So this is joint work with Alex and both of us are at Yahoo Research in Barcelona.
So the things that we looked at is sort of so.
First of all, who uses web search?
So when I say like who uses websites, we look at things such as demographic information.
So what's the age of Web users?
What's The Jets agenda?
What's their race?
What's education ever, and later I will be discussing on how we get these estimates for for our users.
We also looked at sort of.
What do people use web search for?
So by what I mean, what are the Yahoo directory topics they interested in?
Sort of do this search for sports information to.
This works for business information for education, for arts etc etc.

In the last thing said, he looked at sort of how do people use web search and by how I I've been mostly referring to basic session information, so just do they have sort of short session so they have long sessions.
What is sort of the click entropy of the queries?
I mean do they have very focused queries so called navigational queries?
Or do they have broader and informational queries?
And of course, most.
Importantly, how do these things interact?
I mean, do younger people have longer sessions?
Do older people search more for education information etc etc.
OK, so let me first start by explaining the data set we used in our analysis.
So we used 13 months of web search logs for the Yahoo Web search engine and all of our works for you as traffic only.
And so the time period of this study was from October 2018 November 2009.
And overall we use data for 2.3 million anonymized, registered Yahoo users, and all of these users, upon registration, provided us with their birth year with their gender and with the ZIP code.
So with the US ZIP code we only use information or in our study we only used users for users who issued at least 100 distinct.
No 100 queries.
Doesn't matter whether distinct or not during the period of our studies.
And another work, we take a user centric approach so each user was given the same weight.
So whenever we average we average on a per user level, not on a per query level.
So even if there was a user who issued let's say 10,000 queries would be just as important as a user who only issued 100 queries.
So then let me sort of explain how we got the data that I mentioned in particular site with a sort of full data.
So as I said so far for users on registrations, they give us their gender and their birthday and the zip code, but they do not provide us with their education level or with their race or anything.
So but then what we do is so we look at your census data.
So he had to give you an example.
So if you go to this website so this is a publicly accessible website factfinder.census.gov, and if you enter you sip code it will tell you basic demographic information about this zip code.
So for example you see in this particular case in this ZIP code 95054 which is in California.
Only 38% of the population is white.
So with this information and of course you get similar information for the expected income in this area or the expected education level.
For example in this ZIP code, 55 percent 4045% of the population of age 25 or older has a Bachelor degree.
Or, as I mentioned that you get the right information, then we annotate a user from the ZIP code with all this information.
So we'd say like a user from this zip code would be for example 38% wide or would have an expected income of 31,000 US dollars per year.
In terms of income, note that these the census data we used was from 2000 and South since 2000.
Then inflation of about sort of 40%.
So you need to sort of multiply this by effect of 1.4 to get like more realistic estimates of the today's income.
So OK, let me give you like a comparison.
So how do?
How do Yahoo users compared to the US average?
So the US average for income?
For example, in the 2000 census was 21 point, $6000 per year for the Yahoo users.
At least the estimates we got obtaining we obtained from using the ZIP codes was 22 point 9000, so it's slightly higher.
In terms of, what's the fraction that lives below the poverty line overall for the US averages was 12.4% for the Yahoo users was 10.9%.
Again using the estimates from the from the ZIP codes for the Bachelor degree, you see that for Yahoo users is slightly higher than for the US average.
ETC for the affection of white people, it's slightly higher than 12 details on the paper if you're interested.
So overall, if you look at these things, there's a pretty good match so that Yahoo users seem to be pretty representative of the Yahoo of the US population.
But there are some differences.
So first of all, this seems to have a slightly higher income.
Of course they have a computer, so this is really creates a bias.
They seem to be slightly more educated.
They seem to be slightly more wide, and they also seem to be slightly older.
So this is The Who data.
So now let me explain more detail how we obtained the what data.
So what type of topics?
So interesting, so as I mentioned before, we classified queries into the Yahoo directory topic.
So here on the left you see sort of this Yahoo hierarchical directory.
So if you have things such as like entertainment and then under entertainment, you have music or education etc etc.
So the Yahoo directory lists URLs.
It doesn't list queries.
So how do we map sort of queries to this directory?
So let's say we want to map the query wisdom Hong Kong.
To a Yahoo directory topic so then.
We did this so we issued this query to the Yahoo search engine.
And then we looked at the results returned.
Now, internally in Yahoo we have a classifier that classifieds pages, not URLs.
Not not queries specifies pages into the Yahoo directory topics.
So for example for the first return result.
The classifier then internal classifier would output.
This website is about computers and Internet and more specifically about programming and development, and for the second returns results would say this about social science etc etc.
And then we look at all the top 10 results and we do like a majority voting on these things.
So for this query would then say, well this query seems to be about computers and Internet or programming development and more.
To be more specific, because most of the results returned are about this.
So then give you an overview of sort of.
So what do people search for in general?
So the most popular topic overall in our data set was news and media and news media in general, and this topic contains queries such as Facebook, Craigslist, YouTube, Google or Yahoo.
And then the second most popular topic turned out to be about adult content.
Until you have sort of the detailed breakdown of the percent of volume, or also in terms of macro averaged across users, the ranking of the topics is very similar.
So for example, just to make this sort of more concrete.
So on average each user or 11.4% of the users queries is false and sort of this this topic about living Facebook, reckless YouTube and let's say 6.4% falls into the topic of adult content.
So this was the the the what.
But then we've also interested in the House.
So how do people sort of search?
And so one of the things we wanted to look at this like are they like, are they more likely to issue navigational queries?
Or they're more like tissue informational queries?
So distinguish between these two?
We looked at the click entropy and sort of so the click entropy essentially looks like how diverse are the results clicked in response to a query.
And so my focus query mean a query.
With a click entropy of smaller than one.
So if you look at these so here are some popular examples.
Amazon, Craigslist, eBay, etc.
All of these are navigational queries, so the majority of people who issued the query Facebook actually went well.
Then click on the home page for Facebook.
Or if the issue Yahoo Mail the query that they were going to like to click on the corresponding URL rather than searching for information about Yahoo Mail in general.
So this is what we labeled as a focused query.
Then there's a diverse query just to give you the contrast to these are queries with the click entropy of three or higher and you have queries such as American Idol or baby names.
So people searching for baby names do not all click the same URL.
They sort of try out different URLs, so there's not just one URL which everybody has in mind when you change this query.
OK, so then with this data we try to obtain a user submits segmentation according to sort of what people search for.
So for for each user we had a distribution of the topics that this user search for.
For example, here's a user who surged or 50% of this users previous work for sports, 10% for news, 10% for gardening etc etc.
Another user with zero percent sports, 20% use etc.
And so we had such a vector for for all of our just over 2 million users we considered.
And then we clustered these users into 16 different clusters according to sort of what they searched for.
So again, the cluster only used what they search for, not who they are or how they search, only the what they search.
Only the top exchanges.
Today so here you have the classes we obtained.

I mean, I'm not going to go through all of them, there are there in the paper if you're interested, but again, just the thing I want to emphasize issues so the we use the differences in the what to obtain the clusters and then the difference is the other dimension.
Sort of like who falls into a certain cluster or how people search within this cluster which were then induced by using an instructor topics.
So to give you some of the examples of the classes that we found.
So for example, one cluster which is the second one we label.
This baby boomers because so users in this cluster are older than the overall users in terms of the what they search for, their more likely to switch from business and finance related information.
So for how they search for their more likely to issue navigational queries and have sessions with this sort of single click.
So which is again indication for navigational queries.
Another cluster which is worth mentioning relabels liberal females.
So these are people who are much more likely to search for shopping than a random user.
There are mostly women, so 72% of the users in this cluster are are women and also in the last presidential election.
These users were more likely to vote for.
More than random users and their sessions are longer than for other users, which is probably an indication that they sort of compare different products.
Another example, clusters are white Conservatives, so these are older men.
The search lot for automobile and related information for business related information consumer electronics.
The queries are less navigation and others.
The last cluster I want to mention here.
Re label challenged youth.
So these are younger users from lower income regions and they search lot for music in the queries are again more navigational.
So this is sort of like an overall picture without looked like the interplay between these things and more.
And more details.
So for example here, look at the interplay between the age of a user and what people search for.
So here at the top you have the topic distribution for very young users, and then at the bottom you have the topic distribution of what people search for very old users.
So to pick some and you see is that sort of sums.
Each color corresponds to topic and you see that sort of certain topics gets bigger or smaller as people get older or another sort of more or less constant.
So to give you some create examples.
So for example, the topic education is most pronounced among young users, but then as people get older they are less likely to issue queries about education.
The same holds for movies again where young people are most likely to search for movies and people.
Also most likely search for music compared to all the users.
Offer television related information, but there also topics.
Oh yeah, the same holds for games.
There are some topics where the opposite trend towards were all older.
People are more likely to issue queries for certain topics, so this holds for a business and finance related queries.
So the topic the lighter blue of these two is for business and then one on the rights for finance and in general.
Or also gambling so older users are more likely to search for gambling related information.
Um?
And so another few examples.
So if you look at so who's the?
Which is the age group that's most likely to search for reproductive health information.
So these are users in the age bracket between 24 and 32 years, which makes perfect sense if you think about, you know, sort of.
What's the typical age where people worry about these things?
Of whether the older users again are most likely to search for weather related information in terms of military related information, these are also fairly young users, but not extremely young users.
So this already sort of 1.
This was some examples of the interplay between sort of like who uses web search and what they use it for.
Some other examples that we found.
Of course, there's the obvious gender differences where men are more likely to search for sports or adult content, whereas women are more likely to search for reproductive health, arts or families.
Age difference was already went through this on the previous slide.
Income differences so people from lower income regions are more likely to search for music, comics or military.

There also some differences concerning race, so white people or people who live in predominantly white neighborhoods are more like to search for weather and outdoors home and gardening, agriculture and people in predominantly agent neighborhoods are more likely to search for programming and development related.
Formation so this was sort of like how does The Who and the what interact.
But now let's look at how to say how and for what interact.
So again, so there's a so like certain topics attract more navigational queries, not somewhere navigational users.
So like topics such as news media, which again contains things just like Facebook or Craigslist, these are topics that have a higher fraction of navigational queries, queries, or.
Topics that have a higher fraction of informational queries sort of what we label informational users because they have more or less not so trivial sessions.
Longer sessions with more information and queries, so such topics are.
For example, concerned medicine or just ease and condition?
And then sort of.
Finally, of course you can also look at the interplay at The Who and how.
So how do people?
Sergeant, how does this depend on who a person is?
So there's one interesting.
Depends on the education level.
So people will live in a neighborhood with higher education level that they are more likely to issue tail queries or so.
So infrequent queries and they're less likely to use the query suggestions provided.
So like did you mean or also try this and they're also more likely to have shorter sessions, so apparently this indicates that people with a higher education level are better at formulating their.
Information needs.
In terms of H, young people tend to issue more queries in a single session.
It's another thing which is not so obvious.
I said all that users are older.
Users are more likely to issue navigational queries.
And also queries containing like fragments such as stepped up.
Um, another thing which we looked at.
Sort of interesting.
So how do topics?
How do what people search for?
How does this differ with where people live?
I mean, not in terms of like demographic descriptions, but just in terms of like regions.
Which regions of the US?
So here are some reasons we considered and then to give you an example, sort of.
If you look at which is the region with the highest fraction of computer and programming related queries.
So this turns out to be a San Francisco and this is the greater San Francisco area which includes the Silicon Valley.
So where are people most likely?
Search for entertainment and actors related information.
So this is LA which includes Hollywood.
If you look at medicine, this is highest for New York radio.
This is highest for Nebraska, which is a very fairly rural area.
Gambling is highest in Las Vegas.
Travel information is most search for in San Francisco and.
Agriculture is again highest in Nebraska, so all of these.
Makes sense or somewhat stereotypical.

If you're interested in sort of playing with this demographic differences yourself, I invite you to try out this Yahoo product which was launched in November last year and it's based on science developed in Barcelona, so the URL is closed at yahoo.com.

So, for example, if you want to compare the users who issue queries to stock quotes with the users issuing a query such as unemployment benefits, just sort of, you can just type these two queries and compare.

And he will see that users issuing stock quotes are older than users issuing unemployment benefits and also users issuing stock quotes tend to live in higher income areas than users issuing the query on unemployment benefits.
So.
So that's all.
Thanks a lot for your attention.
If you have questions, feel free to email either me or my coauthor, Alex, so my email address is in where at yahooinc.com.
OK, thanks a lot.
